title: Surfing the Seven Seas. Yaharrr...:pirate
content:
What's your stance on piracy?

This question is not limited to music, software and movies, but is applicable to information of any sort.

My vote goes to Option 4. I pirate anything I can--movies, games, music, books, articles, and any other avenues of underground info-grabbing I can get my hands on. However, I also purchase legitimate copies of anything I can that I get the most value out of.

I adamantly refuse to pay to download software, prefering some kind of physical package that's worth putting on display. This includes oldschool games like Keen--I will never buy them from the 3DRealms site unless they start publishing them again. I'm always on the lookout for second-hand copies of the originals, though.

One thing that bugs me about the gaming industry these days is that alot of companies slap together some cheap packaging and chuck a massive box on the shelves padded with a chunk of cardboard and a single CD and, at best, a copy of the manual on the CD. Nothing you can really get your hands on.

Anti-piracy measures, from what I can see, are having the opposite effect to what they're supposed to. Prices are driven up, and thus less people are willing to fork out the stupid amounts of cash being asked, including me. Of course, when they're on special at a reasonable price ($10-15) at a supermarket, then I'm willing to pay.

Anyway... my mind is kinda wrapped around itself at the moment, so if I continue typing it'll end up a relatively incoherent mess. I'll elaborate on some other points when people start flaming me.Cave assectatorem Ductoris Alacris

The development of the hardware, and the greater ability to express every idea that flies into a programmers head, mean that game creators have made the new games congested with every technique in their power. The basic games behind all this are so blurred that people cant catch up. We should go back to basics like Pac-Man and play in an easier, more relaxed way. -Toru Iwatani

title: Re: Surfing the Seven Seas. Yaharrr...:pirate
content:
OK, let's see... first of all, I voted: "I don't like it".

I used to pirate everything when I was young, or rather, I didn't know any better and traded games with friends.
Now that I'm older I do spend money on games, but only games I know I like, meaning I don't spend a fortune on them.

I also sometimes see a nice, old game for a small amount of money, and pick that up.
I recently bought Doom Special Edition (including all 3 original engine games, which was actually cost a bit more than I would've liked), Prince of Persia: Sands of Time (which I haven't installed yet), Max Payne, Black & White and Creature Island combo CD (also for my sister, who as suspected likes this game), and a while ago Duke Nukem Manhattan project.
With these older games I spend very little money, will know my computer will be able to run them, and still get a good amount of gaming pleasure..

I do have some really old games which aren't for sale anymore, meaning there is no other way for me to get them than by downloading them from abandonware sites.
At least some of these were actually released as freeware by their respective developers/distributors.
It know it's technically not legal, but I do not believe I'm hurting anybody by it, and I simply still like playing those games.
I also have MP3's on my computer, quite a bunch of which are free computer game music, but some of which are not.
I have to admit I don't like buying CD's, but I really barely listen to music either.

I do prefer having something tangible when spending money as well.
The older games I mentioned before didn't come with paper manuals, which does sort of bug me.
I like to read those things every now and again when I have a spare minute or 2, waiting for an installation to finish or whatever.
I do however prefer the DVD-style boxes over the old, relatively huge paper/cardboard boxes which had at least 3 different "standards".
Then again the UT box with the extra flap thingy did have "something", but I can live without.

Anti piracy measures as a rule are useless, and REALLY annoying.
On that note, in the Netherlands we have to pay taxes on empty CD's and DVD's, because we will supposedly always put illegal copies on them.
Well, I suppose that would be a solution for the copying problem, not going into wether or not it's a good one, but copying is still illegal, and if you put your home-brew programmes on it, why would you have to pay taxes?
Are we going to have to pay taxes for USB flash drives in the future as well?

Some developers claim games are going to get more and more expansive, and should, because more and more money, time, and other resources are put into them, but in my opinion it simply doesn't work like that.
A movie filled to the brim with expansive special effects doesn't cost a whole lot more than a simple movie of the same length either.
I say games should instead become cheaper, which I am sure will make more, and other people buy them, with the end result of the developers still making more money.

Copies being sold as the real thing are obviously wrong in my book.

OK, I'll wrap it up now.
So... uhm...
*Wrap!*Retodon8

I don't see it as a problem, and I download stuff whenever it suits me.

I think that in most cases when people download something they wouldn't have bought it anyway, either because they don't want it enough at that price or because they can't find it. If they have enough cash that they don't mind forking it over for a product then they'll buy it. In my experience, people like to buy stuff, and will jump at the chance if it's within budget. If they don't have the cash then they won't buy it, and it makes no difference whether they download it or go without. None of the stock that the seller paid to produce has been taken (unlike old school stealing), so the potential for profit is just as high.

Some people are just leeches and download everything, never buying it even though they could easily afford it, and I'm fine with that too. There are freeloaders everywhere and they're nothing to get mad about.________________

title: Re: Surfing the Seven Seas. Yaharrr...:pirate
content:
I agree with that point - I know I only download things when I wouldn't have bought them anyway (so the developers aren't losing out on any money.)

But by the same token (particularly with movies) I download them to see if they're any good, and about 25% of the time they are and I've gone out and bought the DVD. If I wasn't able to download the movie, I wouldn't have gone out and bought the DVD...

And there's also another argument to the "piracy drives up software prices" case - eventually you'd think the price would be driven up so much that buying a game will cost $10 million for the CD. But if that happens, the developer will only need to sell one copy to turn a profit and it doesn't matter if people pirate it then, even if everyone has to pay for the pirate copies [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-wink.gif[/img]

Of course I don't think piracy really drives up the prices, it's consumers. If nobody bought any games over $50, you'd find that it wouldn't take long before all games sold for $50. Just look at other countries around the world - "poor" countries sell the same game much cheaper than "rich" countries simply because if it was sold at the same price across the board nobody in the poorer countries could afford to buy it and they wouldn't sell *any* copies...
